This. Everything I felt while reading Devotion of Suspect X and Salvation of a Saint put into crisp words. Just the other day, I was reminiscing how with western mystery (particularly sherlock or poirot), the readers are kept away from the emotional aspect of the mystery and mystery alone takes precedence over everything else (although, this is more often the case with the Sherlock books than with Poirot). Thinking about them only highlighted how Keigo has combined and balanced the two elements (mystery and emotion) so fluently. Throughout the story, I was rooting for Ayane, wishing that Utsumi was wrong and convincing myself that the murder was accidental or Ikai had something to do with it, all the while perfectly knowing that this was all wishful thinking.

That is what some people call the 'Play God' strategy. Let the readers play 'God'. The readers know the murderer from the start and that creates a kind of suspense as the reader tries to figure out how the murder could have happened and how the detectives will ever figure it out. However, you would have to be at a very high level of writing to be able to make it work, and Keigo Higashino is definitely qualified!

The speech about "we all contribute to the future, not just the geniuses" may feel a bit preachy ... but it's also arguably true, and is especially interesting in the context of this story, because this mirrors the behavior of the chaotic physical systems which form such a large part of the story: even in a deterministic universe (which is itself doubtful given quantum mechanics), certain types of physical system are very hard (read, almost impossible) to predict far into the future because the effect of very small changes can be magnified so greatly over time that they overwhelm seemingly more significant effects.It's indeed kinda ridiculous that Madoka and Kento have the ability to predict such systems, but if we assume "magic," I think it's a neat followup for Madoka to apply this ability to human society to come up with the awesome last line of the book...[I didn't like the ending generally, but that last line was a kicker!]
